page.title: Quantifiers and QP
page.introduction:
Most languages have three sets of quantifiers:
Those meaning all,
other quantifiers such as many or few, and
numbers.
We'll deal with each in turn.
Quantifiers meaning all seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers, but in the same place as degree words like only and just.

form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark the words like all, only, and just with the features Deg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to Deg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs.
Also, mark the word or words meaning all with the features plural quantifier.

In the lexicon, mark those which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any degree words which can occur on either side.
